stem: A client with leukemia begins aggressive chemotherapy. 24 hours later, labs show Phosphorus 6.5, Calcium 7.0, and Uric Acid 12.0. Complete the bowtie to manage this oncologic emergency.

actions.text: Restrict fluid intake to prevent edema

parameters.text: Serum Electrolytes (K, Phos, Ca, Uric Acid)

rationale.correct: TLS = Cell death spilling contents (high K, high Phos, high Uric Acid, low Ca). Priority is flushing the kidneys (Hydration) and lowering uric acid (Allopurinol/Rasburicase) to prevent renal failure. Monitoring Focus: Electrolytes and Kidney function (Urine).
rationale.incorrect: Giving more phosphate will worsen the crisis. Restricting fluids causes uric acid crystals to clog the kidneys. WBC is not the acute monitoring priority during TLS resolution.
clinicalPearls: The most dangerous part of TLS is hyperkalemia causing cardiac arrest and high uric acid causing acute kidney injury.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Low calcium in TLS is usually caused by high phosphate. If you fix the phosphate, the calcium levels usually stabilize.

mnemonic.title: TLS
mnemonic.expansion:
T = Tumor
L = Lysis
S = Syndrome

Key Actions: Initiate aggressive IV hydration (3L/day); Administer PO/IV Allopurinol or Rasburicase
Key Monitoring: Serum Electrolytes (K, Phos, Ca, Uric Acid); Urine Output and pH

reviewUnits.heading: Tumor Lysis Syndrome â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: TLS = Cell death spilling contents (high K, high Phos, high Uric Acid, low Ca). Priority is flushing the kidneys (Hydration) and lowering uric acid (Allopurinol/Rasburicase) to prevent renal failure. Monitoring Focus: Electrolytes and Kidney function (Urine). The most dangerous part of TLS is hyperkalemia causing cardiac arrest and high uric acid causing acute kidney injury.

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” Calcium management
reviewUnits.body: Low calcium in TLS is usually caused by high phosphate. If you fix the phosphate, the calcium levels usually stabilize.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Tumor Lysis Syndrome
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Initiate aggressive IV hydration (3L/day); Administer PO/IV Allopurinol or Rasburicase. Monitor: Serum Electrolytes (K, Phos, Ca, Uric Acid); Urine Output and pH. Giving more phosphate will worsen the crisis. Restricting fluids causes uric acid crystals to clog the kidneys. WBC is not the acute monitoring priority during TLS resolution.
